Posts.Content: I agree with everyone who recommended getting out in the sunshine for a good walk, but you may find that gives you too much time to brood. Do you enjoy audio books? (I can't stand them personally, but a friend of mine found them very useful.) I got myself out of the habit of planning my funeral and generally wallowing by reading huge amounts (Terry Pratchett's Discworld books were perfect) and watching films (Marx Brothers movies, Blues Brothers, The Commitments, Steve Martin) that made me laugh and gave me some lighthearted moments with my husband (his first wife died of breast cancer 20 years ago). Hope things improve for you!
Posts.Title: Cant understand it

Posts.Content: Our cats didn't pick up anything pre my diagnosis, but then again, they're ultra cuddly anyway, so I wouldn't have noticed ... And I will know things are back to normal when I can enjoy a proper cup of tea again. Roll on that day!
Posts.Title: Weird sense of smell ?

Posts.Content: I used Vicks Vaporub on my fingernails and toenails, on the advice of a chemo nurse, and it helped enormously. Oddly enough, 18 months after chemo finished, some of my nails started to 'lift' again, but going back to the Vaporub has helped once again! Sticky and smelly, but it's worth it.
Posts.Title: Confused... light or dark nail varnish during chemo?

Posts.Content: Hope your news is good - but even if it isn't, we're here to talk to! And as someone who was diagnosed in August 2016 and got into a horrible panic, I (and many others here) can attest to the excellent treatment available and the reassurance that it's all doable. Best of luck xxx
Posts.Title: 25 years old with dent and puckering

Posts.Content: When I was on chemo, it should have been easy to fast (although I figure that it's a bit of a daft idea, given that you're already under par and need fuel), as most things tasted utterly revolting - butÂ the steroids made me absolutely ravenous! Something to bear in mind ...
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and fasting

Posts.Content: Has anyone tried this? Does it work? (Frankly, if someone told me cyanide worked I'd give it a go at the moment!)
Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: Thanks, all - I will get some chelated magnesium and see how it goes. Extra calcium absorption sounds like a useful bonus!
Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: Has anyone tried this? Does it work? (Frankly, if someone told me cyanide worked I'd give it a go at the moment!)
Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: Thanks, all - I will get some chelated magnesium and see how it goes. Extra calcium absorption sounds like a useful bonus!
Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: I had six sessions of neo-adjuvant chemo too, and an MRI after the first two FEC sessions showed that the tumour had shrunk by 50%, which meant I could have a lumpectomy instead of a mastectomy! So it was exactly the right plan - hope it works equally well for you.
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvent Chemo

Posts.Content: My eyelashes are growing back curly! Well, not really curly, but at odd angles and a bit wonky, with some longer than others, and my upper lashes seem to be growing in a double row. All very weird ...
Posts.Title: Curly Hair!

Posts.Content: I have three wigs, and (thank heavens!) none of them look anything like my hair on my nine-year-old passport photo, but when I travelled from Edinburgh to Corfu in June there were no issues. I agree that the automatic readers are quite sophisticated, and that relatively few women retain the same hairstyle for 10 years!
Posts.Title: Passport Photo

Posts.Content: My dad died today. He was almost 90 and had been a heavy smoker since he was about 10, so the news wasn't unexpected. It's just so bloody awful to be 300 miles away and kinda tied up for the next few weeks (plus, there's a much-anticipated holiday booked for 3-10 June). He refused to see a doctor, apparently, so there's going to be an inquest, which will (this sounds awful) hopefully delay matters so I can be at the funeral and support my sister and niece. All happens at once, doesn't it?
Posts.Title: Fifth day of radiotherapy, and my sister rings me ...

Posts.Content: It was the worst side-effect of chemo for me, too. Thankfully I got my tastebuds back about two weeks after my last session, although I still can't drink tea, which is infuriating! Some people swear by fresh pineapple chunks (or try freezing chunks), so that may be worth a go. I couldn't stand plain water, but fizzy water did the trick. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Taste

Posts.Content: No, thank heavens, I didn't get shingles! That was one of my fears, though.
Posts.Title: Shingles?

Posts.Content: Best of luck, Purplerules. Keep us updated xxx
Posts.Title: Suspicious cells

Posts.Content: "Oooh, now you can have a bucket list!" My responses? (a) Sod. Right. Off. (b) If I had wanted to climb Everest/visit New York/swim with dolphins, et-bleeding-cetera, I would have done these things already, you twonk. (c) I'm not actually planning to die just yet. You twonk. Good luck!Â
Posts.Title: My annual fund-raising stand-up routine - need more material !

Posts.Content: Coming in late here, but I was told to rub Vicks Vaporub into my finger and toe nails three times a day during and after finishing chemo, and it worked brilliantly. I did get a bit sick of the smell, at which point I moved on to coconut oil - now I religiously paint them with OPI clear nail strengthener, and they look twice as good as they ever did! Cutting them short and wearing rubber gloves really helps, too.
Posts.Title: Nail problem from chemo - urgent advice please?

Posts.Content: Coming in late here, but I was told to rub Vicks Vaporub into my finger and toe nails three times a day during and after finishing chemo, and it worked brilliantly. I did get a bit sick of the smell, at which point I moved on to coconut oil - now I religiously paint them with OPI clear nail strengthener, and they look twice as good as they ever did! Cutting them short and wearing rubber gloves really helps, too.
Posts.Title: Nail problem from chemo - urgent advice please?

Posts.Content: Any day would suit me, in theory!
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: Lemongrass, you might find that you are prescribed extra steroids once you're on Docetaxol. They are helpful - they were for me - and also a lower dose of Tax is an option if you suffer the 'tax truck' pains. And enjoy your wig. If you're anything like me, you'll get addicted!
Posts.Title: First Session of FEC T

Posts.Content: It was lovely to meet you all - had an excellent afternoon! Hope we can do it again soon xxx
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: 2 or 3 March is fine by me!
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: Count me in!
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: Just checking - I have checked Google Maps andÂ found a Zizzi in Princes Square shopping centre, off Buchanan Street,Â and one in the West End - is it the Princes Square one we're meeting at?
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: I'd be happy to set up a meeting in the West End of Glasgow if anyone is interested. It would be great to put faces to names!
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: Looking forward to it - and I'm using the opportunity of a trip to Glasgow to get a new wig!
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: It was lovely to meet you all - had an excellent afternoon! Hope we can do it again soon xxx
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: New wig!
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: New wig!
Posts.Title: 2019 Meet up in Scotland ? Anyone ?

Posts.Content: I've just discovered that there's a weekly LGFB course very close to where I'm going to be having RT. Are they worthwhile? Anything important to know? Thanks in advance!Â
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: I saw my surgeon last Thursday, and we agreed that I should have a few weeks to fully recover from chemo and this persistent and annoying cold, and that my lumpectomy would be at the end of March/early April. I'm booked in for a pre-op check on Monday. Today, I got a phone call to say that my surgery would happen this coming Wednesday! I squawked a bit and said that was just too soon (after all, it's my birthday on Friday!), and asked for it to be postponed. I mean, obviously I want this all sorted asap, but I don't want to feel rushed ... Has anyone else experienced the opposite of delays?!
Posts.Title: Sooner than I expected!

Posts.Content: My local hospice (Cowal Hospice Trust) offers a brilliant patient transport service - all free, and Western Ferries don't require me to pay the passenger fare. It's such a relief not to have to worry about travelling to appointments! Perhaps you could see whether a hospice near you does the same.
Posts.Title: Volunteer drivers

Posts.Content: Thanks, Fiddlercrab!
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: Mind is completely going - I hadÂ seen that photo you shared of your goody bag, and had 'liked' it too! How long before I can no longer use 'chemo brain' as an excuse?!
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: Went on my course today, and it was excellent! Very helpful and good fun, too. Plus, freebies are nice ;-)
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: LOL!
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: Glad to hear that!
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: Hope your mastectomy goes well, and that you are prepared for it! My biggest worry was that I hadn't stockpiled enough books! (I don't do e-readers, BTW!)
Posts.Title: Sooner than I expected!

Posts.Content: I take your point, but I'd rather be in our local bistro being wined and dined on my birthday! And I really doÂ need to stock up on books prior to spending four days in hospital ;-)
Posts.Title: Sooner than I expected!

Posts.Content: ... and I finally feel human again! Celebrated by going to Glasgow and treating myself to a new wig - three wigs may seem excessive, but I'm planning on sticking with them even after my hair grows back, so nyaaah! Feeling very cheerful :-D
Posts.Title: Two weeks since final chemo ...

Posts.Content: Glad we could help - and fingers crossed for your twin.
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Yes, the next time those pink hearts start cropping up on Facebook, I'll point out that pretty much everyoneÂ is 'aware of breast cancer', but very few people are aware that finishing treatment doesn't mean we can snap straight back to 'normal'!
Posts.Title: Annoyed!!!!!

Posts.Content: Oh, by the way - hang on to those deeply attractive surgical stockings. They're expensive, and you can reuse them on your well-deserved flight to somewhere sunny!
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: My biggest fear was that I would have to take my glasses off. I'm extremely short-sighted and feel really vulnerable without my specs or contact lenses. Fortunately they listened when I pleaded to keep them on up until the very last minute. I wasn't concerned about modesty, however. I've had to whip my bra off so many times and for so many people since last August that it's become routine!Â
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Glad we could help - and fingers crossed for your twin.
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Neo-adjuvant chemo shrank my tumour really effectively - the breast surgeon said that they not only had clear margins, but there was barely any cancer left. What was left was scar tissue; so don't worry about the surgeon not getting it all out (I didn't have a marker, BTW).
Posts.Title: Overthinking - random questions

Posts.Content: That made me laugh, Jan! I had to see my GP due to developing a lymphoedema following sentinel node biopsy and just whipped my shirt off, no bra. He went a bit pale and called for a chaperone!Â
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Louise11, the best way to put on crop top bras is - step into them and pull them up! Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Under wear when having surgery

Posts.Content: I suffered with awful pain after my first docetaxel and white cell injection - even moving my eyes sideways hurt! The oncologist reduced the dose by 15% for the remaining sessions and also prescribed extra steroids, and the pain was much more manageable.
Posts.Title: Docetaxel & Herceptin side affects

Posts.Content: Indeed! Flying to Corfu on Saturday for a much-needed sailing holiday Â :-D
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hurrah! X
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hurrah! It does feel brilliant!Â
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hippo birdies from me also!
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: So relieved to have radiotherapy over with, and feeling very lucky to live in Scotland - Beatson West of Scotland Cancer Centre, Royal Alexandra Hospital, Inverclyde Royal and Glasgow Royal infirmary have done amazingly at getting rid of this pesky breast tumour. Can't begin to imagine how much it all cost, but I am very grateful!Â
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hurrah! It does feel brilliant!Â
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hurrah! X
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: So relieved to have radiotherapy over with, and feeling very lucky to live in Scotland - Beatson West of Scotland Cancer Centre, Royal Alexandra Hospital, Inverclyde Royal and Glasgow Royal infirmary have done amazingly at getting rid of this pesky breast tumour. Can't begin to imagine how much it all cost, but I am very grateful!Â
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Indeed! Flying to Corfu on Saturday for a much-needed sailing holiday Â
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Indeed! Flying to Corfu on Saturday for a much-needed sailing holiday Â
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Indeed! Flying to Corfu on Saturday for a much-needed sailing holiday Â :-D
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: A quick point - I took up the offer of staying at a hotel next to the Beatson during my 19 sessions of radiotherapy. Obviously that isn't offered by every health trust and indeed wouldn't suit everyone! However, our local hospice provides a patient transport service, so I didn't have to struggle with luggage on the Mondays and Fridays. Maybe you could see whether a hospice near you offers transport?Â
Posts.Title: Scared to last Chemo

Posts.Content: Update: Muppet took one look at the weather and did a sharp about-turn! Sensible kitty ... So I walked down to town and picked up a book and a lovely pair of boots from the Red Cross shop - a whole 15 minutes' walk! Thanks again for the inspiration - I will try cat-walking again tomorrow!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I'm the same. My reaction was 'it is what it is', and being a bit of a Pollyanna type, I concentrated on the good parts of having treatment for BC (after 50 years of crap hair, I now have three fabulous wigs and can look like I've just stepped out of a very expensive salon whenever I want; I am a lot more knowledgeable about tons of stuff; I realised how lovely my friends are; I am so lucky to live in Scotland where the NHS has spent a small fortune on chemo, scans, RT, medication, surgery etc). The worst bit was telling my husband, whose first wife died of BC 20 years ago, but he took his cue from me and has been brilliant. And strangely, I now feel healthier than I have for years (hot flushes and achy joints notwithstanding)! So it's not just you!
Posts.Title: Abnormal lack of feelings?

Posts.Content: Okay, I'm provisionally in! I have been suffering from such extreme lassitude (can't really call it fatigue), plus the weather has been pretty dreadful in Dunoon, so my main exercise regime for far too long has been reading heavy books! It's blowing a hoolie out there again, but I promise to go out for a walk at some point today, even if it's only to take our newest cat, Muppet (a three-month-old tabby who we adopted by accident) out on the lead to let him get used to the outdoors and inspect his territory. Thanks for the metaphorical kick up the bum!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: All the RT units at the Beatson had handbells - none for chemo for the reasons outlined above. It's seen as tempting fate to ring a bell after chemo when there's always the possibility that you might end up back there, whereas once you have had lots of RT, you're probably not going to have it again!
Posts.Title: A Bell To Ring

Posts.Content: Proud to say that I have neverÂ worn a shellsuit *wanders off feeling smug* Anyway, I have been out for a walk every day since this thread started (twice today, because as soon as I got home the opticians phoned to say my new specs had arrived) - thanks yet again for the inspiration!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: The prescription I receive is Femara, manufactured under licence in Italy - I have never received any made in Spain or Greece!
Posts.Title: Letrozole - side effects and supplements

Posts.Content: UK-based, and I simply told my GP that I needed to have Femara. She agreed. Be forceful!
Posts.Title: Letrozole - side effects and supplements

Posts.Content: *food, not good. Aargh.
Posts.Title: Docetaxel (Taxotere) Aches & Pains!!

Posts.Content: Hannah, I do tend to rave about The Joy of Wigs a lot, because it genuinely has been wonderful for me - my pre-chemo hair was dreadfully pathetic, but now I can have great hair instantly. Thanks for reminding me that women who have long, lovely hair feel utterly bereft when they have to relinquish it. Empathy is the key - and I hope you all get what you love on your head eventually!Â
Posts.Title: Scalp pain and impending hair loss

Posts.Content: *ginger, not finger!Â
Posts.Title: Docetaxel (Taxotere) Aches & Pains!!

Posts.Content: Lots of people have told me that my wigs look better than my real hair. I agree with them! Lots of other people have said, "Nooo. You're fibbing. That's not a wig. It can'tÂ be!" I do enjoy those moments!Â
Posts.Title: Scalp pain and impending hair loss

Posts.Content: I also went for a short cut, and that helped a little, but when my husband shaved it off it felt instantly better. I always hated my hair (thin, fine, greasy), so I was happy to say goodbye to it. Now I have three gorgeous wigs, and can't imagine life without them! I hope you get through the hair loss as well as possible - it willÂ grow back! Frankly, it was eyebrows/eyelashes that I really hated losing, but they reappeared almost overnight about two months post-chemo, twice as thick. And don't forget to keep tissues handy - it's amazing how much you miss nasal hairs when they're gone :-)
Posts.Title: Scalp pain and impending hair loss

Posts.Content: I used to support this campaign -Â until I got cancer :-(Â  I now see exactly why it is frankly horrible (and I speak as someone who was quite glad to lose her head hair!). It's quite likely that Facebook friends of mine will be doing this, and I need a firmly-worded post to pre-empt them in the hope that I can persuade people to fundraise in another manner. Would the contributors to this thread object if I (completely anonymously, and my FB account is not set to 'public') quoted some of the heartfelt comments made here? I promise I won't quote anybody who doesn't contact me with a definite 'yes', but many of you have said it so much better than I can. Thanks in advance XXX
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Tried to submit a complaint, but got a '404' error message ...
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi, wsarahw - I was suffering from burping and indigestion too, and was prescribed omeprazole, which really helped.
Posts.Title: Docetaxel (Taxotere) Aches & Pains!!

Posts.Content: My first taxotere was awful - I was warned that it would feel like being run over by a bus, but this bus reversed over me about six times! My oncologist reduced the next dose by 15% and gave me extra steroids, and it really helped. Cold finger ale helps my grotty mouth, but the only good I could handle was cheesy scrambled eggs - but no toast :-( Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: Docetaxel (Taxotere) Aches & Pains!!

Posts.Content: Thanks, all of you! I will compose a Facebook message tomorrow.Â
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Don't think so - I tried three different browsers Â :-(
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Finally got a chance to post a rant on Facebook (thanks to those who okayed me using their comments!). One response from a friend of mine (who nursedÂ someone through cancer) was "This is the oncological equivalent of blackface". Couldn't have put it better myself! I have also sent in a complaint to Macmillan with the text of my post and comments, and have firmly asked them not to send me a boilerplate response, but I don't hold out much hope ...!
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Yes, there are many better ways to raise money. And the worst bit for me was losing my nasal hair! Bet no one would volunteer for that. People who haven't been through chemotherapy never seem able to understand why Brave the Shave is so offensive to those who have, and I have given up trying to explain it to them.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I'm still slathering Vicks Vaporub into my finger and toenails, and they're hanging on - oddly, they've gone white rather than brown now!
Posts.Title: Nails on 'T'

Posts.Content: Â I really must stop at four - I'm becoming addictedÂ ... ;-)
Posts.Title: See profile pic for wig no. 4!

Posts.Content: I spent two nights in hospital for lumpectomy, but that was simply because I live in a remote area and it was the only way to have me on the ward early enough! Frankly, I would have happily gone home the same day as the op, but they wanted to keep an eye on me for a second night just in case, which I can't really complain about.Â Â
Posts.Title: Length of hospital stay

Posts.Content: Please don't suffer needlessly. Painkillers are a boon during chemo, and if you're going to be on taxotere further on in chemo, then it's almost certain that you're going to be needing them. Some people swear by ibuprofen, some use paracetamol and others need stronger ones (ie, cocodamol). Find out which one works best for you and take it - you've got enough going on at the moment and headaches are something you don't have to put up with! Hope the rest of your treatment goes as smoothly as possible.Â
Posts.Title: Headache

Posts.Content: I had two FEC, four T, with an MRI after the FEC sessions. The MRI showed that the tumour had shrunk by 50%, so I was very happy! Best of luck with your remaining chemo.
Posts.Title: Neo adjuvant chemotherapy, midway scan

Posts.Content: Excellent news! Chemo is horrible, but when you have concrete proof that it's doing the job, it makes it so much more bearable. Have a good Christmas!
Posts.Title: Mri results

Posts.Content: Not strictly relevant to the main thread, but I had my final RT on the Monday and was lounging on a boat in Corfu in 33Â° sunshine by the following Saturday. Yes, I was still cooking, and my onco was a bit iffy about it, but I used lots of factor 50 and kept in the shade, and all was well. And the holiday did me so much good! Hope everyone else manages to get a break.
Posts.Title: Delaying radiotherapy for a few weeks - could it be detrimental?

Posts.Content: It sounds like miscommunication to me. My consultants were very clear that I would have sentinel node biopsy, neo-adjuvant chemo, surgery (mastectomy planned, chemo did the trick and I got away with WLE), followed by RT and 10 years of Letrozole. This was drummed into me, because they understood that a clear plan is helpful. When my surgeon told me that I not only had clear margins, but there was barely any cancer left, just scar tissue, my first reaction was "so I won't need RT!". He made it clear that RT is needed to mop up any stray cells (and it was nowhere near as bad as I expected!). Don't worry, and remember that they want to ensure as much as possible that you don't get a recurrence!Â
Posts.Title: Now I'm really worried

Posts.Content: My chemo nurse told me about a charity called 'Smalls For All', who send lightly-worn bras and new knickers to women and girls in developing countries. I stopped wearing my underwired bras post-sentinel node biopsy and bought a few crop tops/non-underwired bras, but of course I'll need post-surgery ones soon, so I'll be sending off a package to them, as my local charity shops don't accept them and I refuse to chuck nearly-new bras in the bin! And at least someone will benefit from my cancer diagnosis!Â
Posts.Title: Got bras you aren't wearing any more?

Posts.Content: If you look for 'Smalls For All' on Facebook/Google you'll find details of where to send your bras - it's a very good charity!
Posts.Title: Got bras you aren't wearing any more?

Posts.Content: It's horribly scary when it's the unknown, but once you start chemo it all becomes aÂ lotÂ more manageable, I promise. I largely sailed through FEC with zero nausea (shouting 'Feck! Drink! Arse!' a lot helped), apart from the dreaded chemo mouth. T (along with a filgrastim injection a day later) caused severe joint pains all over, but on the next T my oncologist reduced the dose by 15% and gave me extra steroids, and it wasn't too bad after that. And the first FEC sessions reduced my tumour by 50% and I didn't need a mastectomy in the end, so it really was worth it! Good luck, and don't forget to check out the August chemo club thread.
Posts.Title: New chemo starter

Posts.Content: My eyebrows and eyelashes came back quite quickly - about three weeks post final chemo - and they were twice as thick! Natural wastage has thinned the eyebrows again, so I still rely on a good eyebrow pencil, but my eyelashes are better than ever - yay! What really annoys me is that my Down Below hair came back, but has now disappeared again due to Letrozole. I really loathe being hairless in the pube region. But at least I have my nasal hair back!
Posts.Title: Last chemo & hair regrowth

Posts.Content: I had a cannula in my hand the first time, then one in my arm, and they alternated like that each time - I also have good veins. My chief recommendations Â - take a book and drink plenty of water!Â
Posts.Title: New chemo starter

Posts.Content: The worst thing about being diagnosed, for me, was telling my husband. His first wife, Sue, died from BC 20 years ago, and I was less worried about me than him! Thankfully, he took it in his stride, although he was initially worried about me having chemo, but when I pointed out that a lot has changed in 20 years, and that I wanted to throw everything at it, he listened and accepted my views (and chemo actually went very smoothly, and shrank the tumour so effectively that I didn't need a mastectomy!). Secondly - practical help. He took on every household task (including the cat litter trays!) and never complained when I suddenly decided I desperately needed raspberry trifle at 8.30pm! Nothing was too much trouble, even shaving my head (which must have brought back painful memories for him). So (a) listening to me and (b) giving practical help were what made the whole process much better than it could've been. Good luck with your book!
Posts.Title: Support tips for men on how to support their partners the best way...

Posts.Content: The worst thing about being diagnosed, for me, was telling my husband. His first wife, Sue, died from BC 20 years ago, and I was less worried about me than him! Thankfully, he took it in his stride, although he was initially worried about me having chemo, but when I pointed out that a lot has changed in 20 years, and that I wanted to throw everything at it, he listened and accepted my views (and chemo actually went very smoothly, and shrank the tumour so effectively that I didn't need a mastectomy!). Secondly - practical help. He took on every household task (including the cat litter trays!) and never complained when I suddenly decided I desperately needed raspberry trifle at 8.30pm! Nothing was too much trouble, even shaving my head (which must have brought back painful memories for him). So (a) listening to me and (b) giving practical help were what made the whole process much better than it could've been. Good luck with your book!
Posts.Title: Support tips for men on how to support their partners the best way...

Posts.Content: Yup - I'm a lucky woman!Â
Posts.Title: Support tips for men on how to support their partners the best way...

Posts.Content: Yup - I'm a lucky woman!Â
Posts.Title: Support tips for men on how to support their partners the best way...

Posts.Content: I agree that men often focus on the practical aspects and forget to listen properly, but my heart breaks a little when women on this forum feel that their first duty is to cook like crazy, fill the freezer, spring clean the house, etc, prior to surgery/chemo. It's 2017, for heaven's sake! Why are there still men who refuse to learn the basics? In the spirit of equality, I should add that I also maintain our car and take the bins out! Namaste.
Posts.Title: Support tips for men on how to support their partners the best way...

Posts.Content: I agree that men often focus on the practical aspects and forget to listen properly, but my heart breaks a little when women on this forum feel that their first duty is to cook like crazy, fill the freezer, spring clean the house, etc, prior to surgery/chemo. It's 2017, for heaven's sake! Why are there still men who refuse to learn the basics? In the spirit of equality, I should add that I also maintain our car and take the bins out! Namaste.
Posts.Title: Support tips for men on how to support their partners the best way...

Posts.Content: Best of luck to you both. I was diagnosed in August and promptly started planning my funeral - but here I am in April, with a slim lumpectomy scar, three fab wigs and radiotherapy starting on 3 May, along with renewed respect and admiration for the NHS and its excellent staff! Waiting is the worst thing, though.Â
Posts.Title: Indentation

Posts.Content: I also had an almost complete response to chemo, but they did a lumpectomy to make sure. Plus, even though there was virtually no cancer left, there was scar tissue where the chemo had done its work. But I have a nice neat scar, and with a bra on you can't tell the difference! Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy Query

Posts.Content: I was told to use protection for about four days post-FEC, so if you're in the mood, you should be okay. But if you're not, then pick up a good book instead!Â
Posts.Title: Sex after chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I had a bone scan, a CT scan and a heart scan (baseline scans so they knew where I stood). I then had a sentinel node biopsy, which revealed the one affected lymph node, and then had 2 x FEC and 4 x Docetaxol chemo. The FEC shrank my tumour so well that I got away with a very neat lumpectomy, and then it was 19 sessions of radiotherapy, followed quickly by a week spent sailing in Corfu! I now am on Letrozole for 10 years, plus three years of ibandronic acid tablets and calcium/Vit D and B12, and am a happy bunny. It is all doable, I promise, and although chemo took my hair, check my profile pic for how good a wig can be!
Posts.Title: Lymph node affected help needed please?

Posts.Content: The lymph nodes are called 'sentinel nodes' for a reason - they don't mean that the cancer has spread. I had one positive node, but I am here to say that it didn't mean anything sinister - the node was just doing its job. Take a deep breath and distract yourself in whatever way works for you!
Posts.Title: Lymph node affected help needed please?

Posts.Content: Mine usually took a couple of hours (no cold cap) - they brought sandwiches, soup and hot drinks (including herbal teas, hurrah!) while I was there. The biggest delay was usually waiting for Chemoman, as they call the guy who brings the drugs (I said they need to give him a superhero cape!).
Posts.Title: How long do Chemo treatments take?

Posts.Content: I'm just the opposite - when I was diagnosed, I looked at my life and was deeply relieved to realise that I wouldn't change a thing! Good luck with your new venture - it sounds excellent.Â
Posts.Title: Life re-evaluation...

Posts.Content: I kept quiet about my diagnosis for a couple of months - only my husband and our respective (and quite small!) families knew. As someone commented above, I wanted to have a firm plan in place so I wouldn't get bombarded with questions I couldn't answer. Once I knew the score, I posted a 'bad news, good news' status on FB (most of my friends live in England or far-flung places). They have all been really supportive, and I have had only one crass comment ("Oooh, now you can have a bucket list!"), and no one unfriended me - everyone took their cues from my (slightly annoyingly) upbeat Pollyanna-ish attitude, and it's reinforced my view that I am good at choosing friends!
Posts.Title: How to tell friends?

Posts.Content: Just got the results letter from my first post-treatment mammogram - '... no abnormality and no cause for concern'!!! What a relief!
Posts.Title: Phew!

Posts.Content: Batfinkcaz, I felt that too - everything seemed to be going tooÂ well pre-diagnosis! I was almost relieved when I was diagnosed, odd though it sounds.Â
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: I too lost all my get-up-and-go for about a year before diagnosis. To be fair, I was never wildly energetic, but with hindsight I can see that I was in a definite slump.
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: T was worse than FEC for me, but looking back, the only symptoms that reallyÂ bugged me were cardboard mouth and losing nasal hair/eyebrows/eyelashes. I suffered enormous pain after the first T and GCSF injection, but extra steroids and a reduced dose of chemo did the trick. And FEC-T shrank my tumour so well that I didn't need a mastectomy! It'll fly by, and before you know it you'll be celebrating your last session!Â
Posts.Title: Positive FeC-T , or is it all bad

Posts.Content: I was 52kg at the start of chemo and 60kg by the end, but that was chiefly because (a) it was winter and I didn't feel like going out for walks and (b) the dreaded cardboard mouth meant that nothingÂ healthy tasted good, so I mainlined ginger ale, chocolate, red wine and raspberry trifle! In all honesty, I was too thin at 52kg, so putting on weight didn't worry me. Eat what tastes good and get as much exercise as you feel you can handle - but don't beat yourself up if you gain some weight. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Positive FeC-T , or is it all bad

Posts.Content: Honestly, it sounds like a half-filled hot water bottle if I gently tap it! Is this usual? I'm seeing my surgeon on Thursday, but just wanted some reassurance ...
Posts.Title: My post-lumpectomy boob is gurgling!

Posts.Content: Thank you!Â
Posts.Title: My post-lumpectomy boob is gurgling!

Posts.Content: My BCN gave me a ring yesterday evening to see how I was doing, and she said that they would almost certainly not drain it unless they had to, due to the risk of introducing infection. And (hurrah!) I have already had neo-adjuvant chemo, so no issue there. I'll continue to mildly amuse myself by making it gurgle!
Posts.Title: My post-lumpectomy boob is gurgling!

Posts.Content: My lovely ex, and good friend, Mike, lost his elder brother to suicide. A year later, Mike was diagnosed with prostate cancer. His GP refused to believe that anyone under 50 could have prostate cancer, and it had gone into his bones by then. His poor parents had to bury both their sons. When I was diagnosed, my first thought was how darnedÂ lucky I am. I still think that.
Posts.Title: Feeling sad but lucky!

Posts.Content: I have the opposite - constant snivelling and runny nose! Hope someone can assist you.
Posts.Title: Sore nose

Posts.Content: Me too. Finished radiotherapy in May and started Letrozole in mid-June, and went down with a nasty flu virus at the same time. I'm still feeling dreadful, with hot and cold flushes, no energy, aching all over - and of course I don't know whether to blame the Letrozole or whether I have a virus, or both! Seeing the GP today - hope she can help.
Posts.Title: Hello, I've just joined the forum today and was wondering if anyone...

Posts.Content: Aargh. I was 51kg before chemo. I'm 60kg now! I blame cardboard mouth - ginger ale, fruit trifle, Galaxy chocolate, red wine, whisky, curry and cheese. Fruit and veg - no. I sincerely hope that my diet will improve post-chemo, but hey - my chemo nurse says that my bloods would be seriously impressive for someone who *wasn't* undergoing chemo, so I am doing okay!
Posts.Title: Sore nose
